#Text=Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi

#Text=Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi [ 1 ] ( Arabic : أبو إبراهيم الهاشمي القرشي‎ [ 2 ] ; alternative transliterations al-Qurayshi [ 3 ] and al-Quraishi [ 4 ] ) is the current caliph [ 5 ] of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant .
#Text=His appointment by a shura council was announced by ISIL media on 31 October 2019 , less than a week after the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi . [ 6 ]
#Text=Name and identity

#Text=Little is known about al-Hashimi , but his nisbah , al-Qurashi , suggests that he , like Baghdadi , claims a lineage to Muhammad 's tribe of Quraysh , a position that offers legitimacy in some quarters . [ 6 ]
#Text=Al-Hashimi 's name is believed to be a nom de guerre and his real name is unknown . [ 7 ]
#Text=There is some speculation that al-Hashimi is Amir Muhammad Sa’id Abdal Rahman al-Mawla , who is also known as Hajji ' Abdallah . [ 8 ]
#Text=Rita Katz , director of SITE Intelligence Group , believes that it is unlikely that ISIL would " release any video speeches from this new leader or at least ones that show his face " . [ 3 ]
#Text=Nonetheless , on 1 November 2019 , United States president Donald Trump claimed on social media that the United States government had identified al-Hashimi 's true identity . [ 9 ]
#Text=The Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center has speculated that al-Hashimi is of Iraqi nationality . [ 10 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=According to ISIL , al-Hashimi is a veteran in fighting against western nations , [ 7 ] being a religiously educated and experienced commander . [ 11 ]
#Text=He was described as " the scholar , the worker , the worshiper " , a " prominent figure in jihad " , [ 12 ] and an " emir of war " . [ 13 ]
#Text=Leader of ISIL

#Text=Less than a week after the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi , al-Hashimi was elected by a shura council as the new caliph of ISIL , [ 12 ] indicating that the group still considers itself a caliphate despite having lost all of its territory in Iraq and Syria . [ 13 ]
#Text=Al-Hashimi 's appointment was supposedly done in accordance with the advice of Baghdadi , meaning the new emir was named as a successor by Baghdadi himself . [ 14 ]
#Text=Further evidence that al-Hashimi may have been appointed as successor by Baghdadi may be inferred from the relatively quick succession of Baghdadi . [ 3 ]
#Text=Al-Hashimi 's coming to power followed several days of speculation and denial surrounding Baghdadi 's death among ISIL supporters . [ 15 ]

#Text=The general expectation was that al-Hashimi would become " the leader of a frayed organisation that has been reduced to scattered sleeper cells " [ 16 ] and the ruler of a " caliphate of ashes " . [ 3 ]

column1: #Text=Some analysts believed that Baghdadi 's death would likely cause ISIL to splinter , " leaving whoever emerges as its new leader with the task of pulling the group back together as a fighting force " . [ 12 ]

#Text=However , other analysts believed that Baghdadi 's death will not have of an impact on ISIL " in terms of operational capacity " and that it was likely " not to result in the group ’s demise , or really even bring about a decline " . [ 17 ]
#Text=On 3 November , ISIL 's Sinai province pledged allegiance to al-Hashimi . [ 18 ]
#Text=The next day , al-Hashimi received pledges of allegiance from ISIL 's Bangladeshi affiliates [ 19 ] and Somali province [ 20 ] .
